result.story:
A pink drink served in a Martini glass and called The Cosmopolitan is said to have originated in San Francisco in the 1980s, but it wasn't
until 1988--the year Absolut Citron was launched--that the
Cosmopolitan as it is known today was created. Bartender Toby Cecchini
adapted the original recipe, using fresh juice, orange liqueur, a
splash of cranberry, and the first citrus-flavored vodka. The rest is history!
result.name: Absolut Cosmopolitan
result.descriptionPlain: Fill a shaker with ice cubes. Add all ingredients. Shake and strain into a chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with orange.

result.story: For some reason, drink history isn't as well documented as mathematic formulae or Canadian history. The origin of the Bloody Mary is disputed, but our story -- and we'll stick to it -- is that it was invented at The New York Bar in Paris in the early 20s. Might it be the winning color that has kept it in style, ever since?
result.name: Absolut Bloody Mary
result.descriptionPlain: Stir all ingredients in a mixing glass. Pour into a highball glass filled with ice cubes. Garnish with celery and lemon.

result.story: "It has been widely reported that the Bellini got its start in Harry’s Bar in Venice, Italy. That was 70 years ago, and today it’s one of the most classic drinks around. To make peach purée, peel and slice peaches (remove pit; plant pit in backyard) and run through a food processor with simple syrup to taste."
result.name: Absolut Bellini
result.descriptionPlain: Add Absolut Vodka and peach puree into a chilled champagne glass. Top up with champagne.

result.story: There is a story about Gibson -- that it's named after a tee-totaling diplomat named Gibson. As he'd often go to cocktail parties, he'd ask the staff to fill his glass with water instead of a cocktail, and garnish it with an onion to be able to distinguish it from the rest of the guests' drinks. True or false? Don't know, but it's a darn nice drink.
result.name: Absolut Gibson

result.story: Take something classic. Change something about it, and see something completely fresh come out. That's the story of the Mimosa. It's basically a Screwdriver (ABSOLUT and orange juice) with a new twist. And it’s the perfect mix of easygoing, basic down-to-earth drink and upscale, glamorous party cocktail.
result.name: Absolut Mimosa
result.descriptionPlain: Add Absolut Vodka and orange juice into a chilled champagne glass. Top up with champagne.

result.story: The Cape Cod is probably named after the Massachusetts peninsula because they actually grow cranberries there (and the drink contains, well, loads of cranberry juice). But the drink also shares some features with the East-Northern outpost -- the true New Englander knows how to time it for just when the reds match.
result.name: Cape Cod

result.story: The blackberry is one of the more majestic-looking fruits around, and this -- combined with a flourishing cultivation of this bramble -- has currently made it boom in bars all over the globe. Trivia: Superstitious Brits thought that the Devil peed on blackberries on September 29, thus didn't pick them after that date. Muddled, the blackberry is deeply red.
result.name: Vodka Bramble
result.descriptionPlain: Fill a chilled rocks glass with crushed ice. Add all ingredients. Garnish with blackberries.
